Title: Evidence for an amygdaloid projection to premotor cortex but not to motor cortex in the monkey
Abstract: Previous studies in the cat have demonstrated a direct projection from the amygdaloid complex to motor and premotor regions of the neocortex. In the present study both anterograde and retrograde tracer techniques have been used to determine whether a similar projection exists in the monkey brain. We have found that the dorsal, magnocellular division of the basal nucleus of the amygdaloid complex gives rise to a projection to the premotor cortex (Area 6), which terminates principally in layers I and II, and to a lesser extent in layer VI. No component of the amygdaloid complex has been found to project to the motor cortex (Area 4). The amygdaloid projection to Area 6 in the monkey appears to be substantially weaker than other rostrally directed projections from the basal amygdaloid nucleus to orbitofrontal and medial frontal areas, and also relatively weaker than the projection that has been described in the cat.

@Injections.Citation: "We have sought to confirm this finding with an additional experiment in which HRP was injected into Area 4 of one side and into Area 6 of the opposite side" (p. 113)
"We have sought to confirm this finding with an additional experiment in which HRP was injected into Area 4 of one side and into Area 6 of the opposite side" (p. 113)

@Methods.Comments: "For the autoadiographic experiments, 9 monkeys (Macaca fascicularis) were used and 7 received bilateral injections (aimed at different structures) so that 16 injections were available." (p. 113) It is not further explained, if the results are based on the bilateral or unilateral cases or of both.

@Injections.Citation:
"In the course of a study of the efferent connections of the monkey amygdaloid complex in which 3H-amino acids were injected into each of the subdivisions of the amygdala of the macaque monkey we noted that in cases in which the injections involved the magnocelular division of the basal nucleus, anterogradely transported label would be found over Area 6 but not Area 4. 
...Essentially all subnuclei of the amygdaloid complex were involved in at least one injection. " (p. 113)
" Fig. 3. These line drawings ...show the distribution of anterogradely transported isotope following an injection of 3H-amino acids into the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus (DM28L)." (p. 115, legend of figure 3)
"...The injection is centered in the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus (outlined)." (p. 115, legend of figure 2)
"In Fig. 2 the injection site in one of our autoradiographic experiments is shown; in this brain the focus of the injection involves approximately the same region of the basal nucleus in which the majority of retrogradely labeled cells were observed in the previous HRP case" (p. 115)
"In no other case (including those with injections of the parvocellular division of the basal nucleus, the lateral nucleus, or of either division of the basal accessory nucleus) was there any indication of a projection to Area 6." (p. 116)
@Injections.Comments: Case DM28L is the only TAA case with relative precise description of the injection site.

publication.title: Evidence for an amygdaloid projection to premotor cortex but not to motor cortex in the monkey
publication.abstract: Previous studies in the cat have demonstrated a direct projection from the amygdaloid complex to motor and premotor regions of the neocortex. In the present study both anterograde and retrograde tracer techniques have been used to determine whether a similar projection exists in the monkey brain. The amygdaloid projection to Area 6 in the monkey appears to be substantially weaker than other rostrally directed projections from the basal amygdaloid nucleus to orbitofrontal and medial frontal areas, and also relatively weaker than the projection that has been described in the cat.
